Office of Secretary of State Lincoln, Nebraska July 10, 1936 To His Excellency, R. L. Cochran, Governor of the State of Nebraska. Sir: Conforming to the Statutes of the Stale of Nebraska, I submit herewith my report as Secretary of State, for the State of Nebraska for the twenty-four months ending June 30th, 1936. This report sets forth the amount of moneys expended by this department, together with a classified statement of all moneys received by the office as fees. Also a list of the chattel loan organizations having charters. Respectfully submitted, HARRY R. SWANSON, Secretary of State.

FINANCIAL STATEMENT OF HARRY R. SWANSON SECRETARY OF STATE This office collects fees for filing articles of incorporation, cor - poration permits, notary public commissions, registration of brands, certificates of transcripts, trade marks, loan licenses under provision of House Roll No. 44, Session Laws of 1915. REPORT OF AUDITOR OP PUBLIC ACCOUNTS STATE OF NEBRASKA Office of the Auditor of Public Accounts Hon. R. L. Cochran, Governor and Members of the Session of the Nebraska Unicameral Legislature, Lincoln, Nebraska Dear Governor and Members: In accordance with the laws of the state of Nebraska, ch. 84-303, Comp. St. Neb. 1929, I have prepared a biennial report of the state government's business transactions covering the two years from July 1, 1934, to June 30, 1936. This report is made up of numerous statements and supporting schedules, which are listed under Table of Contents on page 12. The resources of the state on June 30, 1936, amounted to $74,287,713.83, or an increase in assets of $2,933,594.26 over June 30, 1934. This increase is made up as follows: Cash on hand $1,575,720.11 Cash due from county treasurers 172,620.63 Accounts Receivable, Income Hospitals 476,145.29 Land, Buildings, and Equipment 803,840.76 $3,028,326.79 Decrease : Bonds of State Trust Funds - 15,111.45 Delinquent Taxes 79,621.08 94,732.53 Net Increase $2,933,594.26 Statement No. 1 reflects the resources of the state as of June 30, 1936. All outstanding and unpaid warrants as of June 30, 1936, have been deducted from the cash balance as of the same date. Accounts Receivable, Insane Hospitals, show an increase of $476,145.29 over the previous biennium. This increase is caused primarily by including all accounts due these institutions from counties and individuals.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS INCREASE IN ASSETS The increase of $803,840.76, Land, Buildings, and Equipment is made up of various increases in all the departments. Miscellaneous Departments increased $154,042.01. Of this amount $151,000.00 is shown in Roads and Irrigation as a result of a physical inventory. An increase of the valuations of the University of Nebraska amounts to $455,403.77. This increase includes the College of Agriculture, Endowment Lands, valued at $116,445.84, not previously included. The Game, Forestation, and Parks Commission shows an increase of $159,200.00, and Penal and Charitable Institutions increased $318,898.27, and State Lands show a decrease of $283,703.28. No computation has been made at any closing period of the current un - paid bills. The State o. Nebraska has no bonded indebtedness. LOSS TO PERMANENT SCHOOL FUND A loss of $39,024.00 was sustained on $50,000.00 of Whitney Irrigation District Bonds belonging to the Permanent School Fund on account of a settlement through Federal Bankruptcy filed in the U. S. District Court, Chadron Division. A loss of $4,800.00 to the Permanent School Fund occurred on the foreclosure of a note and mortgage covering the W% NW% Sec. 14-8-10, Adams County. The State of Nebraska now has title to this tract of land which is handled by the Land Commissioner's office. REGISTRATION OF BONDS During this biennium the office examined and registered bonds of the various subdivisions of the state in the amount of $18,213,923.73, as shown in Statement No. 8. During this period the department ap - proved and registered 404 issues of bonds of the subdivisions of the state, of these 145 issues were original and 259 refunding bonds. Of the $18,213,923.73 bonds registered, only $4,749,633.00 were original bonds, the balance were refunding. Practically all of these bonds were refunded at an interest rate considerably lower than were the original issues, which means a reduction in interest of ' approximately \Vi to 2 per cent, or an annual saving to the taxpayers living in these bonded districts of about $240,000.00. There has been a laudable effort on the part of the various subdivisions to reduce rather than increase their bonded debt, and the very gratifying showing in this respect is reflected in statement No. 9. This encourages us to believe that eventually the same spirit that has made the parent government — the state — famous for its "pay as you go" policy will in time animate the subdivisions and that they will follow the state in its system of planned economy. It will mean millions of dollars saved the taxpayer in interest and expense of issuing bonds. In our opinion bonds should j only

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS be issued in cases where it is absolutely necessary and where a genuine emergency exists. BONDED INDEBTEDNESS Statement No. 9 shows the outstanding bonded indebtedness of the various subdivisions arranged by counties and amounts to $79,349,064.94 on June 30, 1936. The bonds outstanding on June 30, 1934, totaled $93,095,800.00, reflecting a decrease of indebtedness of $13,746,736.00. The above figures do not include $6,860,000.00 of the Omaha Metropolitan Utilities revenue bonds, for the reason that there is a sinking fund of $4,084,131.79 in the treasury of the district with which to pay these bonds: as they become due. The subdivisions are to be congratulated on the very fine showing they have made in, the past two 1 years in reducing the bonded indebted - ness of the various municipal and rural divisions of the state. How - ever, there is a tendency on the part of the subdivisions to ignore both the spirit and letter of the law in reference to making levies for the payment of bonds when they are due. The law requires that the levy be made to pay the interest and also the principal when the bonds are matured. Oftentimes this is not done, and if the levy is made it is in many cases diverted to other uses. This of course necessitates the refunding of many issues. Some issues of bonds have been re - funded so many times that before the bonds are finally paid, the original issue has cost the district in interest alone the amount of the principal, not including the additional expense incident to the refund - ing issues that follow. It is my opinion that the law should be so strengthened as to en - force a sufficient levy to be made to pay bonds at maturity and that it be a criminal offense to divert the money collected for any other purpose. This would insure all bonds being paid at maturity, and the taxpayer would be relieved in his district of the extra burden placed on him because of the seeming disregard of statutes by those who represent him in official positions. COUNTY TREASURER EXAMINATIONS Sec. 26-1309, Comp. St. Neb. 1929, provides for the examination and auditing of all county offices at least once every two years. The law provides for the appointment of two accountants to handle this work. For many years the Legislature has failed to make appropriations sufficient to carry out this mandate relative to all county offices, and the department has had to be content with the audit of county treas - urers only. In keeping with other department reductions the 1933 Legislature reduced the salaries and wages and maintenance fund of the auditor's department $7000.00 and $1500.00 respectively, but in place of this reduction appropriated $10,000.00, especially for audit-

REPORT OF AUDITOR OP PUBLIC ACCOUNTS ■ I ing state and county offices. Inasmuch as the reduction about matched the increase, the department was in very little better shape to function in this respect than it had been heretofore. When William B. Price, former state auditor, took office in 1933, he appointed two county examiners, but soon found that with the rap - idly increasing business of the counties over a period of years, it was impossible for two men to audit even the county treasurers in the time fixed by statute, and as a result of this survey he appointed an assistant examiner. In doing this he was compelled to readjust his salary schedule by reducing salaries, not only of the county treasurer examiners but the others of his office force, and thus spread out his appropriations to fit the circumstances. As a result of this policy, I am able to state that as this biennium comes to a close, every county treasurer in the state has been audited and examined in less than the time limit set by statute, including annual audits for Douglas and Lancaster counties. However, the present accounting system is unsatisfactory for the reason that it has vastly outgrown its limitations. Our present sys - tem might possibly have been sufficient 25 years ago, but the state has grown from an appropriation of $6,000,000.00 a biennium to a $40,000,000.00 business institution. It has become a complex and complicated machine. Almost every other department of state has kept up with the growth of the state except the accounting depart - ment. It is my opinion that this condition could be greatly improved by an amendment to the present statute, providing for the audit and examination of all county offices, state offices, state institutions, and normal schools at least once a year, and charge this audit to the proper fund of the various departments, state institutions, normal schools, and counties. I am convinced that this would be an act of economy for all concerned, not only in better bookkeeping accounting, but it would obviate the necessity of private audits periodically, which are in no sense official audits under our statute. " ■ - - ■ Take for example the state institutions. No systematic official audit has been made of these units for some years, because of the financial limitation placed on the state's accounting department. So far as I have any record county offices, aside from county treasurers, have never been officially audited by the state. Such a system of auditing and accounting as I have suggested above would bring to the legislative body, when it meets biennially, information on which to base its deliberations in the matter of ap - propriations not heretofore available, and at the same time do away with the endless controversies regarding the costs and management particularly of the various departments and units of state government, such as has obtained in the past legislative sessions.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS BANKING AND STATE TREASURER AUDITS The regular session of the Legislature of 1935 appropriated $20,000.00 for a special audit of the banking and receivership divisions of the Department of Banking and also $10,000.00 for a special audit of the administrations of state treasurers William M. Stebbins, T. W. Bass, and George E. Hall. These audits were started under the late William ' B. Price's second term, who died while in office, before the audits were completed. Approximately seven months were required to finish the receivership division of the Department of Banking and this report was submitted to the special or 51st session of the Legis - lature. The disposition of this matter, which was thrashed out by the two houses of the Legislature, is a matter of record and needs no further comment here. The audit and examination of the receivership division covered a period from January 1, 1930, to October 15, 1935. About eleven months was required to complete the audit and ex - amination of the eight years of the administrations of the above named state treasurers, at a cost of $7,352.00. It was the first time in many years that the state treasurer's office had been subjected to a detailed audit and the results clearly vindicate the wisdom of the Legislature in ordering such audit. In my opinion the expense was thoroughly justified. However, in the light of the experience developed in the work of the accountants, I have no hesitancy in recommending and urging upon the Legislature provision for yearly audits of the state treasurer in the future. I am sure if this had been done in the past the temporary school fund would now be richer by nearly $100,000.00 in addition to a more accurate system of bookkeeping and records of bond transactions. LOW TAX LEVY The state tax levy is the lowest since 1921, and comparable with any previous levies since 1915, when the Legislature appropriated something over $6,000,000.00 for the biennium. Since the good roads program was started some twenty years ago the state has built nearly 8000 miles of graveled and paved roads at a cost of approximately $100,000,000.00 without a bond issue or a hangover debt, and every mile of road has been paid for during its construction and completion. In addition to the above, the state is in excellent financial con - dition. At the close of this fiscal year, July 1, 1936, the financial report of the State Treasurer showed resources of $21,621,929.68, •which includes $13,747,005.70 of permanent school funds and $7,874,924.98 cash on hand and in banks, credited to the various funds of the commonwealth.

REPORT OP AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS HOSPITAL MAINTENANCE Much confusion has resulted from an amendment to Sec. 83-732, Comp. St. Neb. 1929, by Senate File 241 of the 1936 regular session of the Legislature. The intent of the Legislature was commendable in that it attempted to fairly distribute the cost of caring for patients in the three hospitals for indigent insane. There had been very little effort to enforce the original statute, which resulted in unfair distri - bution; some counties paying regularly while others did not, making it pretty much of a lopsided proposition. There was and is today very little system used in the collection of the amounts due from counties. The Auditor at the present time is charged with the duty of notifying the counties of these claims, and has no way of checking payments because these payments are sent direct to the state treasurer and placed in the institution cash funds of the hospitals. To obviate this confusion I would recommend that the Board of Control be empowered to notify the counties, rather than the Auditor, and the Board be authorized to keep a set of books in which an account may be kept of those patients who pay their own way through relatives or guardians, and those whom the counties are forced to care for, that each county be required to make a small special levy in keeping with its per capita responsibility concerning these indigents. Thus each county would be paying its fair share, and legislative appropriations for the support of all the institutions could be made accordingly. SALARY AND WAGE REGULATION Before the administrative code law went into effect the Legis - lature fixed the salaries of practically all of the department employees and these salaries could only be changed by legislative act. When the code went into effect in 1919 this privilege was delegated to depart - ment heads whose salaries were fixed by statute. In recent years there has been considerable abuse of this privilege, salaries fixed at the beginning of the biennium are raised promiscuously by some de - partment heads with an excess of estimated cash funds, while other departments with fixed salary and wages must be content with what the Legislature provides. Thus salaries in some departments for the same class of work are clearly out of line with other departments. This raises the cry of favoritism and special privilege. I consider this manifestly unfair, and I would recommend that the Legislature in its wisdom provide that all salaries be fixed at the beginning of the bien - nial period, and that the Auditor be charged with the duty of enforc - ing this mandate. THE DEATH OF AUDITOR PRICE The sudden passing of William B. Price, on August 19, 1935, after having served only about seven months of his second term was

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS one of the tragic events of the administration. It was the first time in the history of Nebraska's 69 years of statehood that an executive officer had died during his term of office. As a result the state ma - chinery was thrown into a state of chaos. No business could be trans - acted until this vacancy was filled. However, Governor Cochran with his usual promtpness in emergencies appointed the writer, who was serving as deputy at the time, and within less than twenty-four hours the machinery of government was again functioning. When Auditor Price took office in 1933, he brought into that de - partment a fund of experience, an efficiency, and a grasp of public questions that at once attracted public attention. His devotion to duty, his rulings in the interest of economy put the office on a high plane during his incumbency. His motto, "A public office is a public trust," he thoroughly demonstrated in his administration of public affairs. IN CONCLUSION I have enjoyed my work as state auditor during the past eighteen months. It is a great privilege and an honor to represent the people in any capacity of public trust, and especially so in as important a state office as the Auditor of Public Accounts. I have attempted to the best of my ability to render service commensurate with the im - portance of the office and the trust imposed in me by Governor Coch - ran, to whom I feel gratefully indebted for my appointment. His co - operation and helpful spirit of inspiration will be a cherished memory long after I have turned over to my successor the duties of the office. I have been fortunate in the personnel of an office force that has worked harmoniously and efficiently and their loyalty has been a source of deep satisfaction. The work of deputy Elgie C. Bute has been of a high order. W. H. Pansing, state accountant, has fulfilled the duties of his office faithfully and with a degree of efficiency that has made his work outstanding. The three county treasurer examiners, Phil Kohl, T. O. Merchant, and Anton Sagl, have set a record for examina - tions that is both pleasing and commendable. The fine spirit of co - operation displayed by most of the departments in their business con - nection with this office has been a delightful experience. I have enjoyed the association with my fellow workers during my somewhat brief incumbency as head of the department, the making of new as well as the loyalty of old friends, which in a large measure compensates for the disappointments, griefs, and trials that go with the responsibility of so important an office. I could not close this foreword without reference to the news - paper reporters. They have proven themselves the acme of their pro - fession and a credit to the newspapers they represent. John M. Thomp-

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS son of the State Journal is dean of the fraternity with a record of 45 years as state house reporter, a reputation of never having betrayed a confidence and still going strong. Harry Dobbins has achieved dis - tinction as a special writer for the State Journal over a period of many years. E. E. Wolfe (only recently retired) for more than a quarter of a century represented the Lincoln Star as its star reporter and was one of the most proficient of his profession. In recent years a younger generation of reporters, in the persons of Kenneth Keller, and Otho K. DeVilbiss, able representatives of the Lincoln Star; Bob Kelley and Irving Perimeter of the United Press and Associated Press respectively, and who also in their capacity as news gatherers represent those two other great dailies, The' World-Herald and Omaha Bee, have been attached to the state house reportorial staff. To have known these men, old and young alike, and my association with them, has been one of the most pleasant features of my job. Respectfully submitted, FRED C. AYRES State Auditor December 1, 1936.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS Lincoln, Nebraska, July 28, 1936. The State Board of Equalization and Assessment met at the office of the Governor at 3 o'clock P. M., with the following members present: Governor Roy L. Cochran, State Auditor Fred C. Ayres, and State Tax Commissioner Win. H. Smith. Absent: Secretary of State Harry R. Swanson and State Trea - surer Geo. E. Hall. The Tax Commissioner submitted the basis for the 1936 State levy, together with the statements submitted by the State Auditor, showing miscellaneous collections for the general fund and the collec - tions by the Liquor Control Commission, for the general fund. BASIS FOR 1936 STATE LEVY The report of the State Auditor shows the appropriations from the state general fund for the biennial period of 1935-1936 to be $11,560,281.24 Less conditional appropriation for the Liquor Control Commission, not used 100,000.00 $11,460,281.24 One-half of which is to be met from 1936 property taxes 5,730,140.62 Less intangible tax 103,893.00 $ 5,626,247.62 Less miscellaneous collections for general fund, as per State Auditor's report 864,076.25 $ 4,762,171.37 Less collections by the Liquor Control Commission for the State General Fund, as per Act of the 1935 Legis - lature 1,138,007.87 $ 3,624,163.50 Less unused appropriations __! 103,996.60 $ 3,520,166.90 which amount is increased 3% in accordance with Sec - tion 77-1007 of the Compiled Statutes of Nebraska for 1929 105,605.00 Total to be raised from property tax levy in 1936 $ 3,625,771.90 The assessed valuation of the state has' been found to be $2,060,835,168, applied to which a levy of 1.76 mills will raise $-3,627,069.90

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS STATE OF NEBRASKA AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS LINCOLN July 18, 1936. Hon. Wm. H. Smith, State Tax Commissioner, Lincoln, Nebraska. Dear Sir: — I beg to submit the following statement of Receipts and Dis - bursements of the Nebraska Liquor Control Commission Cor the year beginning July 1, 1935 and closing June 30, 1936. These figures are compiled from our recent audit closed on May 30, 1936. All transactions of June 1935 were eliminated and all transactions of June 1936 were included. Inasmuch as the opening of a depart - ment causes unusual expense, I am of the opinion the next year's ex - pense will be somewhat reduced. Stamp Sales — Liquors and Wines $ 686,957.28 Beer Stamps 587,381.47 Registration Fees 16,786.00 Miscellaneous Revenue 8,275.71 $1,299,402.46 Expenses 161,394.59 Total Estimated Income $1,138,007.87 Respectfully submitted, Fred C. Ayres, State Auditor. (Signed) W. H. Pansing, State Accountant. Tax Commissioner Smith moved that the state general fund levy for the year 1936 be fixed at 1.76 mills on the dollar valuation. The motion was seconded by State Auditor Ayres, and all present voted aye, as follows: Governor Cochran, Auditor Ayres, and Tax Commis - sioner Smith. There being no further business to come before the Board at this time, it recessed subject to call. (Signed) Wm. H. Smith, State Tax Commissioner and Secy, of the State Board of Equalization and Assess - ment.
